channel.copyright: Copyright 2015 The New York Times Company

item.title: As South Sudan Crisis Worsens, ‘There Is No More Country’
item.description: In the world’s newest nation, the fighting, atrocities and hunger have increased, with no end in sight to the warring leaders’ power struggle.
item.dc:creator: MARC SANTORA
item.media:description: The population of Wau Shilluk, a swampland village on the Nile, has swelled as people have fled their homes seeking safety from marauding soldiers.

item.title: U.S. Says Drone Killed an ISIS Operative
item.description: The Pentagon said that a “person of interest” in the 2012 attack in Benghazi, Libya, died in coordinated airstrikes in Mosul, Iraq, on June 15.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
Tariq bin al-Tahar bin al-Falih al-Awni al-Harzi
item.dc:creator: HELENE COOPER and ERIC SCHMITT

item.title: Optimism for an Agreement on Greek Debt, but Not for Long-Term Stability
item.description: Fears remain that any easing of the Greek crisis when all 28 European Union leaders meet on Thursday and Friday will be short-term.
item.dc:creator: STEVEN ERLANGER and JAMES KANTER
item.media:description: Greeks read news reports in Athens on Monday, when Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras arrived in Brussels for a eurozone meeting.

item.title: Government in Ethiopia Is on Track to Win With 100% of Vote
item.description: Ethiopia’s governing party and its allies are poised to control every seat in the nation’s Parliament, according to official results announced Monday.
item.dc:creator: JACEY FORTIN

item.title: Reversing Course, Pakistan Says Save the Children Can Stay
item.description: Pressure from Western allies will allow the aid agency to continue its operations, though on a smaller scale and with tighter restrictions.
item.dc:creator: SALMAN MASOOD

item.title: Unicef Report Describes Grim Trends for the Poorest Children
item.description: The United Nations Children’s Fund said improvements in national averages had obscured worsening trends among the world’s poorest children.
item.dc:creator: RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: U.N. Report on Gaza Finds Evidence of War Crimes by Israel and by Palestinian Militants
item.description: The report said “impunity prevails across the board” regarding the actions of Israeli forces in Gaza, but also cited the “inherently indiscriminate nature” of rockets fired at Israeli civilians.
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.dc:creator: JODI RUDOREN and SOMINI SENGUPTA
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.media:description: Palestinians mourned members of the Nigim family who were killed during an Israeli airstrike in Jabaliya, Gaza, on August 4, 2014.

item.title: Risk of Extreme Weather From Climate Change to Rise Over Next Century, Report Says
item.description: More people will be exposed to floods, droughts, heat waves and other effects of climate change in the coming decades, according to a British medical journal.
item.dc:creator: SABRINA TAVERNISE
item.media:description: Drought in Puerto Rico has left the La Plata reservoir nearly empty. A study in The Lancet predicts a growing number of people will be affected by extreme weather over the next century.

item.title: Iraqi Families Return to Fragile Stability in Tikrit After Liberation From ISIS
item.description: The Islamic State was driven from Tikrit, the hometown of Saddam Hussein and the largest city the terrorist group has lost in either Iraq or Syria.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: OMAR AL-JAWOSHY and TIM ARANGO

item.title: Computer Failure Leaves State Dept. Unable to Issue Visas
item.description: The country receives an average of 50,000 applications daily, and officials say that medical or humanitarian visas deemed priorities will be issued.
item.dc:creator: KAREN ZRAICK

item.title: E.U. Begins Naval Operation in Mediterranean to Stop Trafficking of Migrants
item.description: The initial phase will involve surveillance, intelligence gathering and patrolling, and calls for the capture and destruction of ships used by traffickers.
item.dc:creator: ELISABETTA POVOLEDO

item.title: Hundreds Die in Heat Wave in Southern Pakistan
item.description: Unusually high temperatures, reaching up to 111 degrees led to the deaths of at least 260 people over three days, many in the port city of Karachi.
item.dc:creator: ZIA ur-REHMAN and SALMAN MASOOD

item.title: Open Source: Egyptian Women Defy Protest Ban to Call for Release of Political Prisoners
item.description: Dozens of Egyptian women defied a nationwide ban on unsanctioned street protests on Sunday, rallying outside the presidential palace in Cairo.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: ROBERT MACKEY

item.title: Greece and Its Creditors Show Signs of Headway in Debt Talks
item.description: Eurozone finance ministers sounded positive after Athens submitted new proposals that would raise some taxes and cut costs by adjusting pensions.
item.dc:creator: JAMES KANTER
item.media:description: Jean-Claude Juncker, right, the European Commission president, gave Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras of Greece a friendly slap on Monday at an impromptu joint news conference.

item.title: Almaty, Kazakhstan, Battles Perceptions and Beijing in 2022 Olympic Bid
item.description: The executives trying to bring the 2022 Winter Olympics to Almaty say their bid is better than Beijing’s, but winning July’s I.O.C. vote will be another matter.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: SAM BORDEN
item.media:credit: James Hill for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Trans-Ili mountain range provides a backdrop to the Sunkar Ski Jumping Complex in Almaty. Every venue in the city's bid is within a radius of about 18 miles.

item.title: Gangi Journal: Sicilian Town Tells Outsiders: Take Our Homes. Please.
item.description: To reverse their town’s loss of population, residents of Gangi are offering houses for free or for nominal prices, provided that the new owners fix them.
item.dc:creator: ELISABETTA POVOLEDO
item.media:credit: Gianni Cipriano for The New York Times
item.media:description: The historic center of Gangi, a Sicilian town whose local administration is giving away abandoned houses. The giveaway is a means to stimulate tourism-related activities and diversify the local economy, which is now primarily dependent on agriculture and animal husbandry.

item.title: Taliban Strike Afghan Parliament as Lawmakers Meet
item.description: No serious injuries were reported in the Parliament attack, which occurred as lawmakers gathered for a third attempt to confirm a defense minister.
item.dc:creator: JOSEPH GOLDSTEIN and ROD NORDLAND
item.media:description: The body of an attacker was carried past a bomb crater in Kabul on Monday. No lawmakers were seriously hurt in the attack.

item.title: Russia Assails Extension of E.U. Sanctions in Ukraine Crisis
item.description: Kremlin officials, who had lobbied hard against an extension, called it self-defeating and said their countersanctions would be extended in response.
item.dc:creator: DAVID M. HERSZENHORN

item.title: Al Jazeera Journalist Is Released by Germany
item.description: The detention at a Berlin airport of Ahmed Mansour, 52, the subject of an Egyptian arrest warrant, had prompted a wave of protest.
item.dc:creator: MELISSA EDDY

item.title: Leaders of South Korea and Japan Speak of Improving Ties
item.description: An exchange of conciliatory remarks came as the officials observed the 50th anniversary of diplomatic relations at embassy events in their respective capitals.
item.dc:creator: CHOE SANG-HUN
